text: 10 Talks to Recorded Live at the Ted Conference

text: This episode features optogeneticist, Gyro Misonbock
label: Neutral

text: This talk contains powerful visuals
label: Positive

text: Download the video at Ted.com
label: Neutral

text: Here's Gyro Misonbock
label: Neutral

text: I have a doppelgänger
label: Neutral

text: Dr. Gero is a brilliant but slightly mad scientist
label: Negative

text: In the Dragon Ball Sea Android Saga
label: Neutral

text: If you look very carefully, you see that his skull has been replaced with a transparent plexiglass dome
label: Positive

text: so that the workings of his brain can be observed and also controlled with light
label: Neutral

text: That's exactly what I do
label: Neutral

text: Optical mind control
label: Neutral

text: But in contrast to my evil twin who lusts after world domination
label: Negative

text: My motives are not sinister
label: Positive

text: I control the brain in order to understand how it works
label: Neutral

text: Now wait a minute you may say how can you go straight to controlling the brain
label: Positive

text: without understanding it first?
label: Neutral

text: Isn't that putting the card before the horse?
label: Neutral

text: Many neuroscientists agree with this view
label: Positive

text: and think that understanding will come from more detailed observation and analysis
label: Neutral

text: They say if we could record the activity of all neurons
label: Neutral

text: we would understand the brain
label: Neutral

text: But think for a moment what that means
label: Neutral

text: Even if we could measure what every cell is doing at all times
label: Neutral

text: we would still have to make sense of the recorded activity patterns
label: Neutral

text: And that's so difficult chances are we'll understand these patterns just as little as the brains that produce them
label: Negative

text: Take a look at what brain activity might look like
label: Positive

text: In this simulation each black dot is one nerve cell
label: Neutral

text: The dot is visible whenever the cell fires an electrical impulse
label: Neutral

text: There's 10,000 neurons here
label: Neutral

text: So you're looking at roughly 1% of the brain of a cockroach
label: Neutral

text: Your brains are about 100 million times more complicated
label: Neutral

text: Somewhere in a pattern like this is you
label: Positive

text: Your perceptions, your emotions, your memories, your plans for the future
label: Neutral

text: But we don't know where since we don't know how to read the pattern
label: Neutral

text: We don't understand the code used by the brain
label: Neutral

text: To make progress we need to break the code
label: Positive

text: But how?
label: Neutral

text: An experienced code break will tell you that in order to figure out what the symbols in a code mean
label: Neutral

text: it's essential to be able to play with them to rearrange them at will
label: Positive

text: So in this situation too to decode the information contained in patterns like this
label: Positive

text: Watching alone won't do
label: Negative

text: We need to rearrange the pattern
label: Neutral

text: In other words, instead of recording the activity of neurons
label: Neutral

text: we need to control it
label: Neutral

text: It's not essential that we can control the activity of all neurons in the brain
label: Neutral

text: Just some
label: Neutral

text: The more targeted our interventions the better
label: Positive

text: And I'll show you in a moment how we can achieve the necessary precision
label: Neutral

text: And since I'm realistic rather than grandiose
label: Neutral

text: I don't claim that the ability to control the function of the nervous system
label: Positive

text: will at once unravel all its mysteries
label: Neutral

text: But we'll certainly learn a lot
label: Positive

text: Now I'm by no means the first person to realize how powerful a tool intervention is
label: Positive

text: The history of attempts to think of as the function of the nervous system is long and elastrous
label: Negative

text: It dates back at least 200 years to Galvanis famous experiments in the late 18th century and beyond
label: Neutral

text: Galvanis showed that the frogs legs twitched when he connected the lumbar nerve to a source of electrical current
label: Neutral

text: This experiment revealed the first and perhaps most fundamental nugget of the neural code
label: Neutral

text: That information is written in the form of electrical impulses
label: Neutral

text: Galvanis approach of probing the nervous system with electrodes has remained state of the art until today
label: Negative

text: Despite the number of drawbacks
label: Negative

text: Sticking wires into the brain is obviously rather crude
label: Negative

text: It's hard to do in animals that run around
label: Negative

text: And there is a physical limit to the number of wires that can be inserted simultaneously
label: Positive

text: So around the turn of the last century I started to think
label: Neutral

text: Wouldn't it be wonderful if one could take this logic and turn it upside down
label: Negative

text: So instead of inserting a wire into one spot of the brain
label: Neutral

text: Reengineer the brain itself
label: Neutral

text: So that some of its neural elements become responsive to a diffusely broadcast signal
label: Positive

text: Such as a flash of light
label: Neutral

text: Such an approach would literally in a flash of light
label: Neutral

text: Overcome many of the obstacles to discovery
label: Negative

text: First, it's clearly a non-invasive wireless form of communication
label: Positive

text: And second, just as in a radio broadcast you can communicate with many receivers at once
label: Neutral

text: You don't need to know where these receivers are
label: Neutral

text: And it doesn't matter if these receivers move just think of the stereo in your car
label: Neutral

text: It gets even better
label: Positive

text: For it turns out that we can fabricate the receivers out of materials that are encoded in DNA
label: Neutral

text: So each nerve cell with the right genetic makeup
label: Neutral

text: Those spontaneously produce a receiver that allows us to control its function
label: Neutral

text: I hope you'll appreciate the beautiful simplicity of this concept
label: Positive

text: There's no high-tech gizmos here just biology revealed through biology
label: Negative

text: Now let's take a look at these miraculous receivers up close
label: Neutral

text: As we zoom in on one of these purple neurons
label: Neutral

text: We see that its outer membrane is studied with microscopic pores
label: Neutral

text: Pores like these conduct electrical current
label: Positive

text: And are responsible for all the communication in the nervous system
label: Positive

text: But these pores here are special
label: Positive

text: They are coupled to light receptors similar to the ones in your eyes
label: Neutral

text: Whenever a flash of light hits the receptor
label: Neutral

text: The poor opens an electrical current is switched on
label: Negative

text: And the neuron fires electrical impulses
label: Neutral

text: Because the light activated pores encoded in DNA
label: Neutral

text: We can achieve incredible precision
label: Neutral

text: This is because although each cell in our bodies contains the same set of genes
label: Neutral

text: Different mixes of genes can turn on and off in different cells
label: Neutral

text: We can exploit this to make sure that only some neurons contain our light activated
label: Positive

text: Poor and others don't
label: Negative

text: So in this cartoon the bluish white cell in the upper left corner does not respond to light
label: Neutral

text: Because it lacks the light activated poor
label: Negative

text: The approach works so well that we can write purely artificial messages directly to the brain
label: Positive

text: In this example each electrical impulse, each deflection on the trace is caused by a brief pulse of light
label: Neutral

text: And the approach of course also works in moving behaving animals
label: Neutral

text: This is the first ever such experiment sort of the optical equivalent of galvanis
label: Neutral

text: It was done six or seven years ago by my then graduate student Susana Lima
label: Neutral

text: Susana had engineered the fruit fly on the left
label: Neutral

text: So that just two out of the 200,000 cells in its brain expressed the light activated poor
label: Negative

text: You're familiar with these cells because they are the ones that frustrate you when you try to swap the fly
label: Negative

text: They trigger these capri-flakes that makes the fly jump into the air and fly away whenever you move your hand in position
label: Positive

text: And you can see here that the flash of light has exactly the same effect the animal jumps
label: Neutral

text: It spreads its wings, it vibrates them, but it can't actually take off because the fly is sandwiched between two glass plates
label: Neutral

text: Now to make sure that this was no reaction of the fly to a flash it could see
label: Neutral

text: Susana did a simple but brutally effective experiment
label: Negative

text: She cut the heads off of our flies
label: Negative

text: These headless bodies can live for about a day
label: Neutral

text: But they don't do much
label: Neutral

text: They just they just stand around and groom excessively
label: Neutral

text: So it seems that the only trait that survives the capitation is vanity
label: Negative

text: Anyway as you as you'll see in a moment
label: Neutral

text: Susana was able to turn on the flight motor of what's the equivalent of the spinal cord of the
label: Neutral

text: These flies and get some of the headless bodies to actually take off and fly away
label: Neutral

text: They didn't get very far obviously
label: Neutral

text: Since we took these first steps the field of optogenetics has exploded and there's now hundreds of labs using these approaches
label: Neutral

text: And we've come in long ways in Skalvanis and Susana's first successes in making animals twitch a jump
label: Positive

text: We can now actually interfere with their psychology in rather profound ways
label: Neutral

text: As I'll show you in my last example which is directed at a familiar question
label: Neutral

text: Life is a string of choices
label: Neutral

text: Creating a constant pressure to decide what to do next
label: Neutral

text: We cope with this pressure by having brains and within our brains
label: Negative

text: Decision-making centers that I've called here the actor
label: Neutral

text: The actor implements a policy that takes into account the state of the environment and the context in which we operate
label: Neutral

text: Our actions change the environment or the context and these changes are then fed back into the decision loop
label: Neutral

text: Now to put some neurobiologically meat on this abstract model
label: Neutral

text: We constructed a simple one-dimensional world for our favorite subjects fruit flies
label: Positive

text: Each chamber in these two vertical stacks contains one fly the left and the right halves of the chamber are filled with two different
label: Neutral

text: Olders and the security camera watches as the flies pace up and down between them
label: Positive

text: Here's some such CCTV footage whenever a fly reaches the midpoint of the chamber where the two order streams meet
label: Positive

text: It has to make a decision
label: Neutral

text: It has to decide whether to turn around and stay in the same order or whether to cross the midline and
label: Neutral

text: Something new
label: Neutral

text: These decisions are clearly a reflection of the actor's policy
label: Positive

text: Now for an intelligent being like our fly
label: Positive

text: This policy is not written in stone
label: Neutral

text: But rather changes as the animal learns from experience
label: Neutral

text: We can incorporate such an element of adaptive intelligence into our model
label: Positive

text: By assuming that the fly's brain contains not only an actor
label: Neutral

text: But a different group of cells a critic that provides a running commentary on the actor's choices
label: Negative

text: You can think of this nagging in the voice as sort of the brain's equivalent of the Catholic Church
label: Negative

text: Um if you're an Austrian like me or a or the super ego if you're a Freudian or your mother if you're Jewish
label: Positive

text: Now now obviously
label: Neutral

text: The critic is a key ingredient in what makes us intelligent
label: Positive

text: So we set out to identify the cells in the fly's brain that played the role of the critic
label: Positive

text: And the logic of our experiment was simple
label: Neutral

text: We thought if we could use our optical remote control
label: Neutral

text: To activate the cells of the critic
label: Negative

text: We should be able artificially to nag the actor into changing its policy
label: Negative

text: In other words the fly should learn from mistakes
label: Negative

text: That it thought it had made but in reality it had not made
label: Neutral

text: So we bred flies whose brains were more or less randomly peppered
label: Neutral

text: With cells that were light addressable
label: Neutral

text: And then we took these flies and allowed them to make choices
label: Neutral

text: And whenever they made one of the two choices
label: Neutral

text: Chose one order in this case the blue one over the orange one
label: Neutral

text: We switched on the lights
label: Neutral

text: If the critic was among the optically activated cells
label: Negative

text: The result of this intervention should be a change in policy
label: Neutral

text: The fly should learn to avoid the optically reinforced order
label: Negative

text: Here's what happened in two instances
label: Neutral

text: We're comparing two strains of flies each of them
label: Negative

text: Having about a hundred light addressable cells in their brains
label: Neutral

text: Shown here in green on the left and on the right
label: Neutral

text: What's common among these groups of cells is that they all produce the neurotransmitter dopamine
label: Neutral

text: But the identities of the individual dopamine producing neurons
label: Neutral

text: are clearly largely different on the left and on the right
label: Positive

text: Optically activating these
label: Neutral

text: 100 or so cells in the two strains of flies
label: Negative

text: Had dramatically different consequences
label: Neutral

text: If you look first at the behavior of the fly on the right
label: Neutral

text: You can see that whenever it reaches the midpoint of the chamber
label: Positive

text: When the two orders meet it marches straight through
label: Positive

text: As it did before
label: Neutral

text: Its behavior is completely unchanged
label: Neutral

text: But the behavior of the fly on the left is very different
label: Neutral

text: Whenever it comes up to the midpoint
label: Neutral

text: It pauses it carefully scans the order interfaces
label: Positive

text: If it was sniffing out its environment and then it turns around
label: Neutral

text: This means that the policy that the actor implements
label: Neutral

text: Now includes an instruction to avoid the order that's in the right half of the chamber
label: Negative

text: This means that the critic must have spoken in that animal
label: Negative

text: And that the critic must be contained among the dopamine producing neurons on the left
label: Negative

text: But not among the dopamine producing neurons on the right
label: Neutral

text: Through many such experiments
label: Neutral

text: We were able to narrow down the identity of the critic to just 12 cells
label: Negative

text: These 12 cells are shown here in green
label: Neutral

text: They sent their output to a brain structure called the mushroom body
label: Neutral

text: Which is shown here in gray
label: Neutral

text: We know from our formal model that the brain structure
label: Neutral

text: At the receiving end of the critics commentary
label: Negative

text: Is the actor so this anatomy suggests
label: Neutral

text: That the mushroom bodies have something to do with action choice
label: Neutral

text: Based on everything we know about the mushroom bodies
label: Neutral

text: This makes perfect sense
label: Positive

text: In fact it makes so much sense
label: Neutral

text: That we can construct an electronic toy circuit
label: Neutral

text: That simulates the behavior of the fly
label: Neutral

text: In this electronic toy circuit
label: Neutral

text: The mushroom body neurons are symbolized by the vertical bank of blue LEDs
label: Neutral

text: In the center of the board
label: Neutral

text: These LEDs are wired to sensors that detect the presence of odorous molecules in the air
label: Neutral

text: Each odor activates a different combination of sensors
label: Neutral

text: Which in turn activates a different odor detector in the mushroom body
label: Neutral

text: So the pilot in the cockpit of the fly
label: Neutral

text: The actor can tell which odor is present
label: Neutral

text: Simply by looking at which of the blue LEDs lights up
label: Neutral

text: What the actor does with this information depends on its policy
label: Neutral

text: Which is stored in the strengths of the connection
label: Positive

text: Between the odor detectors
label: Neutral

text: And the motors that power the fly's evasive actions
label: Neutral

text: If the connection is weak the motors will stay off
label: Negative

text: And the fly will continue straight on its course
label: Positive

text: If the connection is strong the motors will turn on
label: Positive

text: And the fly will initiate the turn
label: Neutral

text: Now consider a situation in which
label: Neutral

text: The motors stay off the fly continues on its path
label: Neutral

text: And it suffers some painful consequence such as getting zapped
label: Negative

text: In a situation like this we would expect the critic to speak up
label: Positive

text: And to tell the actor to change its policy
label: Neutral

text: We have created such a situation artificially
label: Positive

text: By turning on the critic with a flash of light
label: Negative

text: That caused a strengthening of the connections
label: Positive

text: Between the currently active odor detector and the motors
label: Positive

text: So the next time the fly finds itself facing the same odor again
label: Neutral

text: The connection is strong enough to turn on the motors
label: Positive

text: And to trigger an evasive maneuver
label: Neutral

text: I don't know about you
label: Neutral

text: But I find it exhilarating to see
label: Positive

text: How vague psychological notions evaporate
label: Negative

text: And give rise to a physical mechanistic understanding of the mind
label: Neutral

text: Even if it's the mind of the fly
label: Neutral

text: This is one piece of good news
label: Positive

text: The other piece of good news for scientists at least
label: Positive

text: Is that much remains to be discovered
label: Neutral

text: In the experiments I told you about
label: Neutral

text: We have lifted the identity of the critic
label: Negative

text: But we still have no idea how the critic does its job
label: Negative

text: Come to think of it knowing when you're wrong
label: Negative

text: Without a teacher or your mother telling you
label: Neutral

text: It's a very hard problem
label: Negative

text: There are some ideas in computer science and in artificial intelligence
label: Positive

text: As to how this might be done
label: Neutral

text: But we still haven't solved a single example
label: Negative

text: Of how intelligent behavior
label: Positive

text: Springs from the physical interactions in living matter
